constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: CONARA Name: Park Road Conservation Area
LOCCEN Name: Kingston Hill and Park Road

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT
LBCASE LB Address: 11 Park RoadLB Grade: LOCALLB Ref: 195

description: Display of 1no.x Internally illuminated Fascia Sign and 1no.x Internally illuminated Projecting sign.
decision_conditions: No advertisement to be displayed without the permission of the owner of the site or any other person with an interest in the site entitled to grant permission. Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No advertisement shall be sited or displayed so as to - (a) endanger persons using any highway, railway, waterway, dock, harbour or aerodrome (civil or military);(b) obscure, or hinder the ready interpretation of, any traffic sign, railway signal or aid to navigation by water or air; or (c) Hinder the operation of any device used for the purpose of security or surveillance or for measuring the speed of any vehicle. Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Where an advertisement is required under these Regulations to be removed, the site shall be left in a safe condition that does not cause danger, nuisance or hazard to the public or impair visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details on the application form and the approved drawings, the signage hereby granted shall be of static illumination only. The intensity of the illumination of the signage permitted by this consent shall be no greater than 250.00 candelas per square metre. Reason: In the interest of neighbouring amenity  and the free flow of traffic on the highway and road safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extension) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

This consent shall be restricted to a period of five years from the date of the consent.Reason: This condition is specified by the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007

Consultations8no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.Planning HistoryNo planning history recorded.ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the conversion of existing garage into habitable room with associated changes to fenestration.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey detached dwellinghouse. The surrounding properties comprise of predominantly detached and semi-detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; -	The Impact upon Highways; and -	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposals seek to convert the integral garage into a habitable room with associated change from existing garage door to a window of a similar appearance to the existing main windows within the front elevation of the property. This is considered to be an acceptable alteration which would not result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the host dwelling.Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The conversion of the garage and alterations to the fenestration would not cause any materially harmful impacts to neighbouring amenity. There are no side-facing windows proposed.Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the integral garage space, although based on the existing floor plan, it does not appear to be of a size capable of fitting a modern car. Nevertheless, the area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used as a car parking space, and so the conversion would not result in the loss of a space that would impact upon highway safety.Access to the rear garden would be maintained to secure access to secure cycle parking.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered not to result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. In addition adequate car parking space for the property would be retained, to the satisfaction of the Council.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.
There is an allotment garden to the rear, please provide the owner/ occupier's address of the allotment garden to the rear.

Fee required - you have claimed a fee exemption stating that a planning application is being made by the same applicant on the same date for the same site as this prior approval application. No planning permission can be found on record. The fee required for your planning application is £96.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, or online via the Kingston council website.
Application Form - You must list all Adjoining Premises on the Application Form. Please add 39 Ravenswood Avenue, which adjoins to the rear.

Confirmation of Site Address - the application form states that the Site address is 56 Bond Road, while some of the submitted plans now state "56A" Bond Road. Please confirm the site address and provide plans that are consistent with the application form, either by amending the application form, or the address in the project box on the plans.
